title: Jeremiah Chapter 48 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 48 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 48 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 48.

questions.question: Against which nation does the LORD of hosts speak in Jeremiah 48:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Moab
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:1 clearly states that the LORD of hosts speaks against Moab.

questions.question: What is the fate of Nebo as described in Jeremiah 48:1?
questions.correctAnswer: It is spoiled
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:1 says, 'Woe unto Nebo! for it is spoiled.'

questions.question: What is said about the praise of Moab in Jeremiah 48:2?
options: There shall be no more praise of Moab
questions.correctAnswer: There shall be no more praise of Moab
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:2 states, 'There shall be no more praise of Moab.'

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 48:7, who shall go into captivity with his priests and princes?
questions.correctAnswer: Chemosh
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:7 says Chemosh shall go forth into captivity with his priests and princes.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 48:10 say about those who do the work of the LORD deceitfully?
questions.correctAnswer: They are cursed
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:10 states, 'Cursed be he that doeth the work of the LORD deceitfully.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Jeremiah 48:11: 'Moab hath been at ease from his youth, and he hath settled on his ____, and hath not been emptied from vessel to vessel.'
questions.correctAnswer: lees
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:11 uses the word 'lees' to describe Moab's condition from youth.

questions.question: What will happen to the horn and arm of Moab according to Jeremiah 48:25?
options: The horn is cut off and the arm is broken
The horn will grow strong and the arm will prosper
The horn will blow and the arm will fight
The horn will be honored and the arm lifted
questions.correctAnswer: The horn is cut off and the arm is broken
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:25 says, 'The horn of Moab is cut off, and his arm is broken.'

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 48:26, Moab magnified itself against whom?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:26 says, 'for he magnified himself against the LORD.'

questions.question: Where were the inhabitants of Moab instructed to dwell according to Jeremiah 48:28?
questions.correctAnswer: In the rock
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:28 instructs the inhabitants to 'dwell in the rock.'

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 48:35 says that the LORD will cause those who burn incense to their gods in Moab to continue doing so.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:35 states the LORD will cause to cease those who offer and burn incense to their gods in Moab.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 48:38 compare Moab to after being broken?
options: A vessel wherein is no pleasure
questions.correctAnswer: A vessel wherein is no pleasure
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:38 says Moab is broken like a vessel wherein is no pleasure.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 48:42 states that Moab will be destroyed because they trusted the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:42 says Moab shall be destroyed because he magnified himself against the LORD, not because they trusted Him.

questions.question: Which city is mentioned as taken in Jeremiah 48:41?
questions.correctAnswer: Kerioth
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:41 states 'Kerioth is taken.'

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 48:47 promises that the captivity of Moab will be restored in the latter days.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:47 says, 'Yet will I bring again the captivity of Moab in the latter days.'

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 48:18, who is called to come down from their glory and sit in thirst?
questions.correctAnswer: Daughter that inhabits Dibon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:18 calls the daughter that inhabits Dibon to come down from her glory and sit in thirst.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 48 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 48 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A believer is trusting in their own works and treasures rather than in God. Based on Jeremiah 48, what warning would you share?
options: They will be taken captive along with their idols and leaders.
They will be blessed abundantly and prosper.
God will multiply their treasures and works.
They will receive immediate forgiveness without repentance.
questions.correctAnswer: They will be taken captive along with their idols and leaders.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:7 warns that because Moab trusted in its works and treasures, it would be taken captive along with Chemosh and his priests and princes. This teaches the importance of trusting God rather than self-reliance (verses 7, 8, 42).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 48 instruct believers to respond when facing destruction or calamity?
options: Flee to safety and save your lives like the heath in the wilderness.
Trust in your own strength and ignore the dangers.
Build strongholds and rely on your own might.
Remain in your place and resist without fear.
questions.correctAnswer: Flee to safety and save your lives like the heath in the wilderness.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:6 advises fleeing to save lives, being like the heath in the wilderness, showing that in times of danger, prudence and seeking safety are wise (verses 6, 18, 44).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 48 say about the consequences of pride and magnifying oneself against the LORD?
options: They lead to destruction, derision, and captivity.
They bring honor and long life.
They result in divine promotion and riches.
They cause others to follow and respect you.
questions.correctAnswer: They lead to destruction, derision, and captivity.
questions.explanation: Verses 26, 42 show that Moab's pride and magnifying itself against the LORD resulted in being made drunk, wallowing in vomit, derision, and destruction. This teaches humility and trust in God (verses 26, 42, 29).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with overconfidence in their own strength for spiritual battles. What biblical truth from Jeremiah 48 would you share?
options: Human strength is insufficient; reliance on God is essential.
One must always fight alone without help.
Confidence in self is the key to success.
questions.correctAnswer: Human strength is insufficient; reliance on God is essential.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:14 and 41 question Moab's confidence in being mighty men for war and describe their hearts as fearful. This reflects the need to rely on God rather than human strength (verses 14, 41, 42).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 48 teach about honesty and faithfulness in doing God's work?
options: Those who do God's work deceitfully or hold back their sword from blood are cursed.
Deception in God's work is acceptable if it benefits many.
Keeping back the sword is a sign of mercy and is rewarded.
God overlooks deceit in service if intentions are good.
questions.correctAnswer: Those who do God's work deceitfully or hold back their sword from blood are cursed.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:10 clearly states that those who do the LORD's work deceitfully or keep back their sword from blood are cursed, emphasizing integrity and obedience in service (verses 10, 8, 38).

questions.question: Based on Jeremiah 48, how should a believer respond when their 'vine' or blessings are spoiled by trials and loss?
options: Mourn and cry out to God with a contrite heart.
Ignore the loss and pretend all is well.
Abandon faith and seek worldly comfort.
questions.correctAnswer: Mourn and cry out to God with a contrite heart.
questions.explanation: Verses 31 and 32 describe God howling and mourning for Moab's loss, teaching believers to lament their trials and seek God in sorrow, not bitterness or denial (verses 31-33).

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 48 teaches that God will permanently abandon His people without any hope of restoration.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:47 promises that God will bring back the captivity of Moab in the latter days, showing hope of restoration after judgment (verses 47, 42).

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 48 condemns those who fail to act faithfully in God's work and those who avoid righteous judgment.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:10 curses those who do God's work deceitfully and those who withhold the sword from blood, emphasizing the need for faithful obedience and justice (verses 10, 8).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 48 encourages believers to be like the ______ in the wilderness when fleeing danger.
questions.correctAnswer: heath
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:6 uses the analogy of fleeing like the heath in the wilderness to describe prudent escape from danger, teaching wise self-preservation (verses 6, 28).

questions.question: What practical lesson about stewardship and trust can be drawn from Moab's reliance on its works and treasures in Jeremiah 48?
options: Trusting in material wealth and personal achievements is futile without God.
Accumulating treasures guarantees God's favor and protection.
Stewardship is unnecessary if one has strong works.
One should rely solely on their own abilities.
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting in material wealth and personal achievements is futile without God.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:7 shows that Moab's trust in its works and treasures led to captivity, teaching that true security comes from God, not material or personal achievement (verses 7, 11, 12).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 48, what attitude should believers have when facing God's discipline and correction?
options: Humility and repentance rather than pride and denial.
Ignoring the discipline and continuing as before.
Seeking revenge on those who bring correction.
questions.correctAnswer: Humility and repentance rather than pride and denial.
questions.explanation: The chapter emphasizes Moab's pride and downfall (verses 29, 30), showing that humility and repentance are the proper responses to God's discipline (verses 13, 30).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 48 illustrate God's justice in dealing with nations that oppose Him?
options: God brings swift and inescapable judgment upon them.
God ignores their sins and lets them prosper indefinitely.
God rewards them for their strength and pride.
God delays judgment indefinitely to show mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: God brings swift and inescapable judgment upon them.
questions.explanation: Verses 8, 25, and 44 describe how no city shall escape judgment and the horn of Moab is cut off, illustrating God's sure and swift justice (verses 8, 25, 44).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with despair after suffering loss. According to Jeremiah 48, what hope can you share about God's future restoration?
options: God promises to restore and bring back captivity in the latter days.
Loss is permanent with no hope of renewal.
God forgets those who suffer and does not restore them.
Restoration depends solely on human effort.
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to restore and bring back captivity in the latter days.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:47 assures that despite judgment, God will restore Moab in the latter days, offering hope to believers enduring trials (verses 42, 47).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 48 teach about the importance of prayer and lament during trials?
options: God expresses lament and calls for mourning over loss, teaching believers to lament sincerely.
Prayer and lament are unnecessary during trials.
Believers should hide their sorrow and appear strong at all times.
Lamenting shows weak faith and should be avoided.
questions.correctAnswer: God expresses lament and calls for mourning over loss, teaching believers to lament sincerely.
questions.explanation: Verses 31, 36, and 38 show God mourning over Moab's ruin, demonstrating that lament is a proper response to suffering and a form of prayer (verses 31, 36, 38).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 48, what does the breaking of the 'strong staff' and 'beautiful rod' symbolize for believers facing hardship?
options: The loss of support and strength, calling for reliance on God.
A sign to abandon faith and seek worldly help.
Proof that God has forsaken His people permanently.
questions.correctAnswer: The loss of support and strength, calling for reliance on God.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:17 laments the breaking of the strong staff and beautiful rod, symbols of strength and leadership, teaching believers to seek God’s strength amid loss (verses 17, 42).

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 48 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 48.

questions.question: What is the primary reason given in Jeremiah 48 for Moab's impending destruction?
options: Because Moab magnified itself against the LORD
Because Moab allied with Israel's enemies
Because Moab refused to pay tribute
questions.correctAnswer: Because Moab magnified itself against the LORD
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:42 states that Moab shall be destroyed from being a people because it magnified itself against the LORD, highlighting pride as the central cause.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 48, which deity is mentioned as going into captivity alongside his priests and princes?
questions.correctAnswer: Chemosh
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:7 mentions Chemosh going into captivity along with his priests and princes, indicating the downfall of Moab's national god.

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Jeremiah 48:10 to describe those who do the LORD's work deceitfully?
questions.correctAnswer: They are cursed
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:10 explicitly states that cursed be he that doeth the work of the LORD deceitfully, showing divine condemnation of false service.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 48:25, what specific parts of Moab are said to be cut off and broken?
questions.correctAnswer: The horn and the arm
questions.explanation: Verse 25 uses the imagery of the horn being cut off and the arm broken as symbols of Moab’s loss of strength and power.

questions.question: Which cities are mentioned together in Jeremiah 48 as examples of those that will face destruction?
questions.correctAnswer: Dibon, Nebo, and Bethdiblathaim
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:22 lists Dibon, Nebo, and Bethdiblathaim among the cities upon which judgment will come, illustrating the comprehensive nature of Moab’s downfall.

questions.question: Jeremiah 48:40 uses the figure of an eagle spreading its wings over Moab. What is this imagery intended to symbolize?
questions.correctAnswer: Sudden and overwhelming invasion
questions.explanation: The eagle spreading its wings is a common biblical metaphor for swift conquest or judgment, as seen in Jeremiah 48:40, symbolizing the coming destruction upon Moab.

questions.question: What literary device is prominent in Jeremiah 48:17-19, where inhabitants are called to lament and ask about the fate of Moab?
questions.correctAnswer: Lamentation and personification
questions.explanation: These verses invoke lamentation and personify Moab’s cities and inhabitants, emphasizing the emotional and communal impact of judgment.

questions.question: Which city is repeatedly mentioned as a strategic location and site of destruction in Jeremiah 48?
questions.correctAnswer: Heshbon
questions.explanation: Heshbon is mentioned in Jeremiah 48:2, 34, and 45 as a notable city involved in Moab’s downfall and a place where enemies gather or fire comes forth.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 48 indicates that Moab will never be restored after its destruction.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:47 declares that God will bring again the captivity of Moab in the latter days, implying future restoration.

questions.question: The phrase 'his taste remained in him, and his scent is not changed' in Jeremiah 48:11 alludes to what aspect of Moab's condition?
questions.correctAnswer: Complacency and unrepentant pride
questions.explanation: Verse 11 uses metaphorical language to describe Moab’s settled complacency and refusal to be humbled or emptied, reflecting spiritual pride.

questions.question: What is the significance of the repeated curses in Jeremiah 48:10 in the context of ancient Near Eastern covenant theology?
options: They emphasize the seriousness of covenant faithfulness and punishment for deceit
They are poetic filler with no real covenantal meaning
They predict military victories for Moab
questions.correctAnswer: They emphasize the seriousness of covenant faithfulness and punishment for deceit
questions.explanation: The curses in Jeremiah 48:10 highlight the breach of covenant obligations, a central theme in ancient Near Eastern treaties and biblical law.

questions.question: Which symbolic action does Jeremiah 48:12 describe as coming upon Moab to humble it?
options: Sending wanderers to cause Moab to wander and break its vessels
A flood to wash away the land
questions.correctAnswer: Sending wanderers to cause Moab to wander and break its vessels
questions.explanation: Verse 12 depicts God sending wanderers to empty and break Moab’s vessels, symbolizing judgment that disrupts and devastates.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 48:31-33 use agricultural imagery to describe Moab’s destruction?
options: Loss of the vine, summer fruits, vintage, and winepresses
questions.correctAnswer: Loss of the vine, summer fruits, vintage, and winepresses
questions.explanation: These verses lament the loss of agricultural prosperity, symbolizing the total devastation of Moab’s land and livelihood.

questions.question: Jeremiah 48:26 compares Moab’s downfall to what kind of humiliating experience?
questions.correctAnswer: Wallowing in vomit after intoxication
questions.explanation: Verse 26 uses vivid imagery of drunkenness followed by shame and derision to describe Moab’s humiliating fall due to pride.

questions.question: What is the authorial intent behind the repeated naming of Moabite cities in Jeremiah 48:21-24?
options: To emphasize the totality and inevitability of Moab’s destruction
To highlight only a few key cities spared
To list places of Moabite worship
questions.correctAnswer: To emphasize the totality and inevitability of Moab’s destruction
questions.explanation: The detailed listing serves to underscore that no part of Moab is exempt from judgment, reinforcing the theme of comprehensive destruction.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 48 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 48 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary reason for Moab's destruction as proclaimed by the LORD in Jeremiah 48?
options: Because Moab magnified itself against the LORD
Because Moab was attacked by foreign nations
Because Moab worshiped the God of Israel
Because Moab was faithful to its covenant
questions.correctAnswer: Because Moab magnified itself against the LORD
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:42 states that Moab shall be destroyed because it magnified itself against the LORD. This reflects God's righteous judgment against pride and rebellion (Isaiah 2:12; Proverbs 16:18; James 4:6; 1 Peter 5:5).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 48, what will happen to the idol Chemosh and his priests?
options: Chemosh shall go forth into captivity with his priests and princes
Chemosh shall be exalted over all gods
Chemosh shall protect Moab from its enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Chemosh shall go forth into captivity with his priests and princes
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:7 reveals that Chemosh and his priests will be taken into captivity, signifying the futility of idolatry and God's sovereignty over all false gods (Exodus 12:12; Isaiah 46:1-2; Habakkuk 2:18-19; Acts 17:29).

questions.question: What curse does the LORD pronounce in Jeremiah 48:10?
options: Cursed be he that doeth the work of the LORD deceitfully
Cursed be he that builds altars to other gods
Cursed be the nation that does not keep the Sabbath
Cursed be the man who does not honor his father
questions.correctAnswer: Cursed be he that doeth the work of the LORD deceitfully
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:10 pronounces a curse on those who perform the LORD's work deceitfully and on those who refrain from bloodshed when necessary. This reflects the seriousness of faithfulness and justice in God's service (Deuteronomy 32:5; Malachi 3:8-9; 2 Corinthians 11:13-15; Revelation 22:15).

questions.question: How does the LORD describe Moab’s former attitude before judgment comes?
options: At ease from his youth, settled on his lees, and not emptied from vessel to vessel
Always repentant and humble before God
Faithful and obedient to the covenant
Zealous for the God of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: At ease from his youth, settled on his lees, and not emptied from vessel to vessel
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:11 describes Moab as having been complacent and secure, not experiencing purification or captivity, leading to stagnation and pride (Psalm 78:57; Proverbs 1:32; Isaiah 56:10; Luke 18:8).

questions.question: What imagery does the LORD use to describe the coming judgment and destruction of Moab?
options: Like a broken vessel with no pleasure
Like a flourishing tree in the garden
Like a victorious warrior on the battlefield
Like a river overflowing with blessings
questions.correctAnswer: Like a broken vessel with no pleasure
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:38 uses the imagery of a broken vessel with no pleasure to depict Moab's shattered state, emphasizing the totality of God's judgment (Psalm 2:9; Isaiah 30:14; Jeremiah 19:11; Revelation 18:21).

questions.question: Which cities in Moab are specifically mentioned as being taken or destroyed in Jeremiah 48?
questions.correctAnswer: Kiriathaim, Nebo, Bozrah, Dibon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:1, 18, and 22-24 list cities such as Kiriathaim, Nebo, Bozrah, and Dibon as being confounded and destroyed, highlighting God's judgment upon the entire land (Joshua 13:9-12; Isaiah 15:1; Ezekiel 25:8-11; Amos 2:1-3).

questions.question: What is the significance of the LORD saying 'Make ye him drunken' in Jeremiah 48:26?
options: It symbolizes Moab's humiliation and loss of control
It indicates a celebration of Moab's victory
It means Moab will be filled with joy from the LORD
It commands Moab to offer wine to the priests
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes Moab's humiliation and loss of control
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:26 uses the metaphor of drunkenness to portray Moab's humiliation and disgrace due to pride against God, consistent with biblical themes of judgment bringing abasement (Isaiah 29:9-10; Habakkuk 2:15; Nahum 1:10; Luke 21:34).

questions.question: What future hope does God give to Moab at the end of the chapter?
options: God will bring again the captivity of Moab in the latter days
Moab will be completely destroyed forever with no restoration
Moab will conquer Israel and rule over the nations
Moab will build a temple to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring again the captivity of Moab in the latter days
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:47 promises restoration after judgment, indicating God's mercy and faithfulness to bring back the captivity of Moab, a theme consistent with the hope of restoration in Scripture (Jeremiah 30:3; Ezekiel 37:21-22; Isaiah 11:11-12; Acts 3:21).

questions.question: What does the LORD say about the worship practices in Moab in Jeremiah 48:35?
options: He will cause to cease those who offer in high places and burn incense to their gods
He will bless their offerings and incense
He will command Moab to build altars to Him
He will not judge Moab's worship practices
questions.correctAnswer: He will cause to cease those who offer in high places and burn incense to their gods
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:35 declares that God will end the idolatrous worship in Moab, emphasizing His intolerance for false worship and idolatry (Exodus 20:3-5; Deuteronomy 12:2-3; 1 Kings 18:21; Romans 1:25).

questions.question: How does the LORD describe the reaction of Moab's mighty men at the time of judgment?
options: Their hearts shall be as the heart of a woman in her pangs
They shall fight valiantly and win
They shall rejoice and be glad
They shall be indifferent and unmoved
questions.correctAnswer: Their hearts shall be as the heart of a woman in her pangs
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:41 uses this metaphor to express the intense fear and anguish that will overwhelm Moab's warriors, reflecting the totality of God's judgment (Isaiah 13:8; Joel 2:6; Revelation 6:16; Psalm 55:5).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 48 say about Moab's trust and treasures?
options: Because Moab trusted in its works and treasures, it shall be taken
Moab's treasures will protect it from enemies
Moab has no treasures or works to trust in
Moab's trust in God will save them
questions.correctAnswer: Because Moab trusted in its works and treasures, it shall be taken
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:7 explains that Moab's misplaced trust in its own works and riches leads to its downfall, illustrating the biblical principle that trusting in anything except God leads to destruction (Psalm 49:6-7; Jeremiah 17:5; Matthew 6:19-21; 1 Timothy 6:17).

questions.question: In Jeremiah 48, what is said about the fate of Moab’s sons and daughters?
options: They will become priests of Chemosh
They will be spared from destruction
questions.correctAnswer: They are taken captives
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:46 states that Moab's sons and daughters will be taken captives, showing the comprehensive nature of the judgment and the consequences of rebellion against God (2 Kings 24:14; Lamentations 1:5; Ezekiel 12:13; Jeremiah 29:14).

questions.question: What metaphor describes the movement of Moab as it flees judgment, according to Jeremiah 48:9 and 40?
options: Like an eagle flying and spreading its wings
Like a lion stalking its prey
questions.correctAnswer: Like an eagle flying and spreading its wings
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:9 and 40 use the imagery of wings and an eagle to depict Moab's desperate flight and the swiftness of judgment, consistent with biblical use of eagles to symbolize speed and divine intervention (Exodus 19:4; Deuteronomy 32:11; Isaiah 40:31; Revelation 12:14).

questions.question: What is the tone of the LORD’s heart toward Moab as expressed in Jeremiah 48:31 and 36?
options: A heart of mourning and lamentation
A heart of anger without any mercy
A heart of rejoicing over their downfall
questions.correctAnswer: A heart of mourning and lamentation
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 48:31 and 36 express God's sorrow and mourning for Moab despite judgment, revealing the compassionate and merciful nature of God who laments over the downfall of sinners (Ezekiel 9:8; Hosea 11:8; Luke 19:41; 2 Peter 3:9).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 48:25 mean when it says, 'The horn of Moab is cut off, and his arm is broken'?
options: Moab’s power and strength will be broken by God
Moab will gain strength and defeat its enemies
Moab will build new horns for their altars
questions.correctAnswer: Moab’s power and strength will be broken by God
questions.explanation: The horn symbolizes strength and power in biblical imagery; its being cut off and the arm broken in Jeremiah 48:25 illustrate the complete removal of Moab's power by the LORD (1 Samuel 2:10; Psalm 75:5-7; Ezekiel 29:21; Hebrews 10:12).
